choices.text: Increase dose of haloperidol
Change haloperidol to clozapine
Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol

questions.text: A patient of Schizophrenia was started on antipsychotic drug haloperidol. Few hours later, he presented with torticollis and muscular dystonia. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Give benztropine

 

When a patient on haloperidol develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) like torticollis and muscular dystonia, the next best step is typically to administer an anticholinergic medication like benzhexol or benztropine to alleviate these side effects. Increasing the dose of haloperidol would likely worsen the EPS, while changing to clozapine is an option for patients with severe EPS or a history of non-response to other treatments. Fluphenazine is unlikely to be significantly different from haloperidol in causing EPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose of haloperidol: Increasing the dose of haloperidol is not the appropriate response when a patient develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as torticollis and muscular dystonia. It can exacerbate these side effects.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is less likely to cause EPS compared to typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Switching to clozapine can be a reasonable option to manage EPS.

 

Option C. Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol: Fluphenazine is another typical antipsychotic and is not expected to be significantly different from haloperidol in terms of causing EPS. Switching to fluphenazine may not effectively address the EPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to manage extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) caused by antipsychotic medications. It can be an appropriate choice to alleviate the torticollis and muscular dystonia.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and abdominal pain. There is a history of 1 blood transfusion in the past. On examination, he had icterus and mild splenomegaly. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sickle cell disease

 

The given scenario with increased HbA2, HbF, and S spikes on electrophoresis suggests sickle cell disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The fundamental molecular lesion: The basic genetic defect in HbS is a single point mutation in one amino acid out of 146 in the hemoglobin molecule—there is a substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6-residue position of the beta -globin, producing HbS.  This causes sickle-shaped red blood cells to be produced due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

 

Infection, dehydration, and acidosis are all risk factors for sickling.

 

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

 

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Vaso-occlusive phenomenon due to obstruction to capillary blood flow by sickled red cells upon deoxygenation or dehydration:
    • Microinfarcts affecting particularly the abdomen, chest, back and joints and are the cause of recurrent painful crises in SS.
    • Microinfarcts involving most commonly the spleen (splenic sequestration, auto splenectomy), bone marrow (pains), bones (aseptic necrosis, osteomyelitis), lungs.
    • (Pulmonary infections), kidneys (renal cortical necrosis), CNS (stroke), retina (damage) and skin (ulcers), and result in anatomic and functional damage to these organs.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Hemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta thalassemia: Typically presents with severe anemia and requires frequent blood transfusions. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2 and HbF but does not show a significant S spike.

 

Option B. HbC disease: Characterized by the presence of hemoglobin C, which does not cause the severe symptoms seen in sickle cell disease. Electrophoresis would show HbC rather than HbS.

 

Option D. Acute coronary disease: Not relevant to the presentation described, as it does not explain the recurrent infections, abdominal pain, icterus, and splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is characterized by the presence of HbS, leading to recurrent infections, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, and splenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and an S spike. The genetic mutation involves the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

choices.text: IFA supplementation is administered only during pregnancy.
100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient.
Supplementing IFA during the First trimester is adequate.
IFA is started from the second trimester of pregnancy onwards, continues during lactation till 6 months.

questions.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat program aims to reduce anemia through six targeted interventions. Correct regarding administration of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IFA is started from the second trimester of pregnancy onwards, continues during lactation till 6 months

 

  • The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program is a government initiative in India aimed at reducing the prevalence of anemia across various age groups. The strategy follows a "6x6x6" approach – 6 target beneficiaries, 6 Interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.
  • 6 Target beneficiaries - 6 to 59 months old Children; 5 to 9 year old children; 10-19 years old adolescents, reproductive-age women (20-49 year), pregnant women, and lactating mothers.
  • For pregnant women, Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation is a key intervention. IFA is administered starting from the second trimester of pregnancy and is continued throughout the remainder of the pregnancy (180 days). This supplementation is then repeated during the first six months of lactation, also for 180 days. The supplementation is given regardless of the hemoglobin status of the woman, making it a primary preventive measure against anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFA supplementation is administered only during pregnancy: This statement is incorrect because IFA supplementation continues during the first six months of lactation after the pregnancy period, not just during pregnancy.

 

Option B. 100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient: This is incorrect as the recommended course for IFA supplementation in both pregnancy and lactation is 180 days, not 100 days.

 

Option C. Supplementing IFA during the First trimester is adequate: This option is incorrect because IFA supplementation typically begins in the second trimester of pregnancy, not the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program should begin in the second trimester of pregnancy and continue through the first six months of lactation, with a recommended course of 180 days each during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: A public health official notes that there were 60 infant deaths and 5,000 live births in the past year. What denominator should she use to calculate the infant mortality rate? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1000

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated using the formula:

 

 

The denominator of 1000 is used to standardize the rate for easy comparison across different regions and populations.

 

In this case:

 

 

Remember:

 

SRS bulletin 2022 - India IMR: 28 per 1000 live births 

 

NFHS 5 (2019-21)- India IMR: 35 per 1000 live births 

 

(IMR of Kerala - 12 per 1000 live births and Japan 2 per 1000 live births)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard denominator for calculating and expressing the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is 1000 live births.

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. What is the ideal agent for distention? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal saline

 

 Explanation:

 

  • In bipolar cautery, electricity has to be conducted from one electrode to the other. So normal saline is preferably used.
  • If a monopolar resectoscope is used, then a non-electrolyte solution like glycine is required.

 

Fluid media in Hysteroscopy:

 

The following distension media can be used in hysteroscopy

 

  • CO2: Good for diagnostic procedures but not for operative hysteroscopy
  • Normal Saline
    • Not to be used with monopolar electrocoagulation
    • Good for minor procedures using bipolar instruments/ office procedures as there is very less risk of electrolyte imbalance
  • Dextran 70
    • Useful in patients with bleeding as it does not mix with blood
    • Can cause anaphylaxis, electrolyte imbalance ans fluid overload
  • Low viscosity, nonconductive fluids like: 1.5% Glycine, 3% sorbitol and 5% mannitol
    • Used in operative hysteroscopy using monopolar resectoscopes
    • Safe as there is no electrolytes to disperse the current and impede the electrosurgical effect
    • Associated with electrolyte disturbances and fluid overload

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal saline is the ideal distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery due to its suitability in conducting electricity between electrodes without causing significant electrolyte imbalance.

 

Ref: Page no 793, Novaks Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy. She came to the hospital after one week with acute pain in the abdomen with features suggestive of perforation. An X-ray showed the following picture. Identify the type of offense for which the surgeon can be held responsible? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Res ipsa loquitur

 

  • The X-ray indicates surgical scissors accidentally left behind during surgery.
  • The surgeon can be held guilty for Res ipsa loquitur.
  • "Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself."
  • The negligent act by the doctor is obvious from the Xray and the patient need not prove the negligence.
  • Conditions to be fulfilled to prove negligence:
  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • There was no contributory negligence from the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: Refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation. It is not applicable here as the negligence was directly related to the surgery.

 

Option C. Res judicata: Refers to a matter that has been adjudicated by a competent court and therefore cannot be pursued further by the same parties. It is not relevant to the context of proving negligence.

 

Option D. Vicarious liability: Refers to the liability of one party for the actions of another, typically an employer for an employee. This does not directly apply to the surgeon's individual negligence in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of surgical instruments left inside a patient post-operation is a clear case of negligence, aptly described by the legal principle of "Res ipsa loquitur," meaning the fact speaks for itself.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from fever and he is diagnosed with condition caused by a lactose fermenting bacteria, he is advised for culture, Which culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mac conkey agar

 

Culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter - MacConkey agar

 

It is used to distinguish lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

it is a selective and differential culture medium

 

Contents of MacConkey agar: Peptone, Lactose, Agar, Sodium Taurocholate

 

 

Lactose fermenters seen as pink colonies, non-lactose fermenters seen as colorless or pale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bile salt agar: Incorrect. Bile salt agar is primarily used for the isolation of enteric pathogens, particularly Salmonella and Shigella, but it does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

Option C. LJ media: Incorrect. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) media is used for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Option D. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar: Incorrect. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar is used for the cultivation of fungi, including yeasts and molds. It is not used to differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to distinguish lactose fermenters, which appear as pink colonies, from non-lactose fermenters, which appear as colorless or pale colonies.

questions.text: A patient presenting with headaches, hypertension, and elevated metanephrines should undergo which diagnostic investigation? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MIBG scan

 

  • Given the symptoms and the elevated metanephrines patient seems likely to have pheochromocytoma , and  an MIBG scan or a CT abdomen would be the most appropriate investigations to confirm the diagnosis of a pheochromocytoma. The MIBG scan offers more specific targeting of the type of tissue involved in pheochromocytoma, making it particularly useful if initial CT results are ambiguous or if surgical planning is necessary.
  • This is a specific type of scintigraphy used to locate neuroendocrine tumors, particularly pheochromocytomas. MIBG is structurally similar to norepinephrine and can be labeled with iodine-123 or iodine-131, allowing it to be visualized using a gamma camera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sestamibi Scan: This is primarily used for detecting parathyroid adenomas and is not suitable for diagnosing pheochromocytoma.

 

Option C. PET Scan (Positron Emission Tomography): While a PET scan is useful in oncologic imaging and can detect metabolically active tumors, it is not as specific as MIBG for pheochromocytoma but may be utilized depending on availability and specific circumstances.

 

Option D. CT Abdomen: This is an effective and rapid diagnostic tool to visualize the adrenal glands and assess for the presence of a tumor. A CT scan can provide detailed images that help in determining the size and location of adrenal masses.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Diagnostic investigation of choice for pheochromocytoma is MIBG scan.

questions.text: An infant is brought to OPD with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT reveals periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

 

Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital rubella syndrome: Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections. Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles). Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

Option B. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periventricular calcifications on neuroimaging, along with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia, are characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: de-Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves tendon sheath of which two muscles? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic. The examiner places patient’s thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction. In positive test this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the opposite thumb is relatively painless.

 

 

Finkelstein’s test – de Quervain’s tenosynovitis

 

  • Differential diagnosis: 
    • Scaphoid non-union
    • Arthritis at the base of thumb
    • Intersection syndrome
       
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is the inflammation of the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

choices.text: Formed by the internal oblique aponeurosis and transversus abdominis aponeurosis
Forms the posterior wall of inguinal canal
Protects the superficial inguinal ring to maintain integrity of inguinal canal
Runs parallel to the inguinal ligament

questions.text: For the conjoint tendon, all are true except:  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Runs parallel to the inguinal ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The conjoint tendon does not run parallel to the inguinal ligament. Instead, it runs obliquely and inserts into the pubic crest and pectineal line, thereby reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal but not parallel to the inguinal ligament.

 

The conjoint tendon, also known as the falx inguinalis, is a critical structure in the anatomy of the inguinal region. It is formed by the aponeuroses of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. This structure plays an essential role in maintaining the integrity of the inguinal canal and preventing hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formed by the internal oblique aponeurosis and transversus abdominis aponeurosis: This statement is true. The conjoint tendon is indeed formed by the fusion of the internal oblique aponeurosis and the transversus abdominis aponeurosis.

 

Option B. Forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal: This statement is also true. The conjoint tendon contributes significantly to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, providing support and reinforcing this area.

 

Option C. Protects the superficial inguinal ring to maintain integrity of inguinal canal: This statement is true. The conjoint tendon helps protect the superficial inguinal ring by forming a shutter-like mechanism that reduces the risk of inguinal hernias by maintaining the canal's integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The conjoint tendon is formed by the internal oblique and transversus abdominis aponeuroses and plays a crucial role in reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and protecting the superficial inguinal ring. It does not run parallel to the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Mode of action of Dicumarol? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K inhibition

 

Dicumarol acts as an anticoagulant by inhibiting Vitamin K. Specifically, it inhibits the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is necessary for the regeneration of reduced Vitamin K. This reduced form of Vitamin K is required for the carboxylation of certain clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X). By inhibiting this process, Dicumarol reduces the clotting ability of blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D Inhibition: Dicumarol does not inhibit Vitamin D. Vitamin D is primarily involved in calcium homeostasis and bone metabolism. Dicumarol's anticoagulant effect is not related to any interference with Vitamin D metabolism or function.

 

Option C. Vitamin A Inhibition: Dicumarol does not inhibit Vitamin A. Vitamin A plays a role in vision, immune function, and cell growth but is not involved in the mechanism of action of Dicumarol or in the blood clotting process.

 

Option D. Vitamin E Inhibition: Dicumarol does not inhibit Vitamin E. While Vitamin E has antioxidant properties and some influence on blood coagulation, the anticoagulant effect of Dicumarol is not mediated through Vitamin E.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin K acts as a coenzyme for the carboxylation of glutamic acid residues present in the proteins such as blood clotting factors.
  • This reaction is catalyzed by a carboxylase (microsomal). It involves the conversion of glutamate (Glu) to y-carboxyglutamate (Gla) and requires vitamin K, O2 and CO2.

 

 

  • The formation of y-carboxyglutamate is inhibited by dicumarol, an anticoagulant found in spoilt sweet clover. Warfarin is a synthetic analogue that can inhibit vitamin K action.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 540

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Factories Act? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories 

 

  • The Factories Act, established in 1948, specifically prohibits the employment of children under 14 years of age in factories. 
  • This legislation was enacted to ensure the protection of children from labor exploitation and to promote their welfare by restricting their employment in industrial environments.

 

FACTORIES ACT:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defense, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48hrs per week or less than 9hrs per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Factories Act of 1948 critically mandates that children under the age of 14 must not be employed in factories, reflecting the law's strong stance on child labor and its emphasis on the health and safety of young individuals.

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low BP and elevated JVP. What is the likely JVP finding? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent y descent

 

The clinical presentation of muffled heart sounds, low blood pressure, and elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) suggests cardiac tamponade. In cardiac tamponade, the JVP is elevated, and the typical waveform finding is a prominent x descent with a blunted or diminished y descent. This pattern is due to the restricted filling of the right atrium and ventricle during diastole because of the pressure exerted by the pericardial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent a wave: This is seen in patients with atrial fibrillation, where there is no organized atrial contraction.

 

Option C. Prominent y descent: This is seen in patients with constrictive pericarditis, where there is a rapid early diastolic filling, known as Friedrich's sign.

 

Option D. Absent x descent: This is a feature of tricuspid regurgitation, where the backward flow of blood during systole reduces the x descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the JVP waveform shows a prominent x descent with an absent or blunted y descent. This is due to the restricted filling of the right heart chambers caused by the pericardial fluid, leading to characteristic clinical signs such as muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and elevated JVP

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG displays a rhythm with broad QRS complexes at a high rate, consistent with ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT is characterized by three or more consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of more than 100 beats per minute. The presence of such a pattern, particularly with a stable, repetitive form as seen in the ECG, strongly points to VT rather than other types of arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ECG: This option is incorrect as the ECG clearly shows an abnormal rhythm with broad QRS complexes, indicative of an arrhythmia originating below the AV node.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Ventricular fibrillation is characterized by irregular, chaotic electrical activity without identifiable QRS complexes, P waves, or T waves. The rhythm shown here is too organized and regular to be VF.

 

Option D. Misplaced leads: Misplaced leads causes positive p in aVR with normal intervals - R wave progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular tachycardia is identified by regular, broad QRS complexes at a rapid rate, distinct from the irregular pattern of ventricular fibrillation and the organized, narrower complexes typically seen with supraventricular rhythms and correct lead placement. Identifying VT on an ECG is critical due to its potential severity and the need for prompt treatment.

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

 

The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Among the given options, Biopsy with histopathologic examination would be the investigation for definitive diagnosis on this patient.

 

The primary reason that appears to be facilitating Mucorales spores to germinate in people with COVID-19 is

 

  1.  An ideal environment of low oxygen (hypoxia)
  2. high glucose (diabetes, new-onset hyperglycemia, steroid-induced hyperglycemia)
  3. Acidic medium (metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis [DKA])
  4. High iron levels (increased ferritins)
  5. Decreased phagocytic activity of white blood cells (WBC) due to immunosuppression (SARS-CoV-2 mediated, steroid-mediated or background comorbidities) coupled with several other shared risk factors including prolonged hospitalization with or without mechanical ventilators

 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.

 

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. Due to invasion of the blood vessels, mucor fungus causes ischemic necrosis presenting as a black eschar, involving inferior turbinate, palate or the sinus. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

Confirmation of diagnosis is by biopsy and histopathologic examination which shows aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

 

 

MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT.

 

Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice – black turbinate sign is seen

 

 

Post-contrast T1-weighted coronal MR image shows non enhancing soft tissue, “black turbinate sign,” within the left maxillary sinus (asterisk). The mucosa of the inferior turbinate and a portion of the left middle turbinate demonstrate focal lack of the enhancement (arrowheads).

 

Management

 

  • Antifungal therapy with Amphotericin B
  •  Surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
  •  Treatment of underlying cause
  • Control of blood sugars in diabetic patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Useful for assessing the extent of disease, especially in identifying orbital and central nervous system involvement. It provides detailed images that help in planning the extent of surgical debridement.

 

Option C. Serum Ferritin: Elevated ferritin levels are commonly seen in mucormycosis due to the fungus’s use of iron from the host, which aids its growth. While not diagnostic, high ferritin levels can support the suspicion of mucormycosis in the right clinical context.

 

Option D. HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): This test reflects long-term glucose control and is crucial in managing diabetic patients. Although it does not diagnose mucormycosis, poor glycemic control indicated by a high HbA1c value is a risk factor for the development of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge along with the following CT scan. On suction cleaning, there is thick mucin that contains eosinophils, Charcot-Leyden crystals. What would be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allergic fungal sinusitis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge. The presence of thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, as well as the CT findings, are indicative of allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS). AFS is characterized by the accumulation of eosinophils and allergic mucin in the sinuses, often resulting in hyperdensities on CT scans.

 

Treatment is always surgical exploration (removal of fungal mass)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal Ball: A fungal ball, or mycetoma, typically involves a single sinus (commonly the maxillary sinus) and appears as a mass of fungal elements without significant allergic mucin or eosinophils. It does not usually present with eosinophils or Charcot-Leyden crystals in the discharge.

 

Option C. Chronic rhinosinusitis: Chronic rhinosinusitis involves prolonged inflammation of the sinuses but does not specifically present with the eosinophilic mucin and Charcot-Leyden crystals seen in AFS. The CT findings in chronic rhinosinusitis do not typically show the hyperdensities seen in AFS.

 

Option D. Fulminant fungal sinusitis: Fulminant fungal sinusitis is a rapidly progressive infection seen in immunocompromised patients and involves extensive bony destruction and tissue invasion. The CT scan would show significant bone destruction and possibly extension into adjacent structures, which is not evident in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic fungal sinusitis is characterized by unilateral nasal obstruction, thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, and hyperdensities on CT scans, without extensive bony destruction.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Crowning
  2. Engagement
  3. Restitution
  4. External rotation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:

 

  1. Engagement: This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  2. Descent: The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  3. Flexion: The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  4. Internal Rotation: The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  5. Crowning: The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  6. Extension: The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis.
  7. Restitution: The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  8. External Rotation: The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  9. Expulsion of the rest of the body: The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. B, A, D, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.

 

Option C. B, C, A, D: This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.

 

Option D. B, D, A, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 145

choices.text: Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate→ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release
Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal
Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens

questions.text: Identify the correct order of End plate potential at the neuromuscular junction: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

 

Explanation:

 

At the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the sequence of events leading to muscle contraction begins with the binding of acetylcholine (Ach) to its receptors on the motor end plate. This binding opens ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, allowing an influx of sodium ions, which depolarizes the muscle membrane and generates an action potential. The action potential travels along the motor neuron to the axon terminal, where it triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels. The entry of calcium ions into the axon terminal facilitates the exocytosis of Ach into the synaptic cleft, which then binds to receptors on the muscle fiber to propagate the signal for muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release:
This sequence incorrectly initiates with the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels before Ach is released. In reality, Ach must first be released to bind to these channels and cause their opening. 

 

Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal:
Ach release is a result of Ca²⁺ entry, not the initial step. This option reverses the correct order of events.

 

Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens:
This sequence incorrectly places the action potential at the motor end plate before Ach release. The action potential at the motor end plate is a result of Ach binding, not the precursor to Ca²⁺ entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction is:

 

Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoma Esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of an elderly female presenting with symptoms such as progressive dysphagia, loss of appetite and weight loss along with the given barium study which shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins. These findings are suggestive of Carcinoma Esophagus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Is a motility disorder of esophagus and appears as a corkscrew esophagus.

 

Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma: Is a benign neoplasm of the esophagus and on barium swallow it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass well outlined by barium.

 

Option D. Esophageal webs: Refers to an esophageal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient presenting with progressive dysphagia for solids and significant weight loss, the presence of irregular narrowing and shouldered margins on a barium swallow is highly suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. Diagnostic confirmation typically requires upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and biopsy. For tumor staging, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is used for T and N staging, while PET-CT is utilized for M staging.

questions.text: Which is not a branch of facial artery in the face?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mental

 

The first part of the maxillary artery gives rise to the mental artery as a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery.

 

The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery that runs a tortuous course through the submandibular region of the face, supplying blood to the muscles of facial expression, submandibular gland, and other structures in the face. The facial artery gives rise to several branches, including the superior and inferior labial arteries, which supply blood to the upper and lower lips, respectively. The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the lateral aspect of the nose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Nasal: The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the side of the nose.

 

Option C. Superior Labial: The superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies the upper lip and surrounding areas.

 

Option D. Inferior Labial: The inferior labial artery is also a branch of the facial artery, and it supplies the lower lip and surrounding regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery. Instead, it is a branch of the inferior alveolar artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. The mental artery supplies blood to the chin and lower lip.

questions.text: The longitudinal growth of the bone is affected by fracture of which region of the bone? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epiphyseal plate

 

The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate or physis, is responsible for the longitudinal growth of long bones in children and adolescents. It consists primarily of cartilage, made up of type II collagen, which progressively ossifies to contribute to the bone's lengthening. This growth plate remains active until it closes after puberty, marking the end of the bone's longitudinal growth. Any fracture affecting this area, such as a Salter-Harris fracture, can disrupt this growth process, potentially leading to growth disturbances or deformities.

 

The other regions of the bone (diaphysis, epiphysis, and metaphysis) are involved in different processes, but they do not directly influence the longitudinal growth as the epiphyseal plate does.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphysis: This is the shaft of the long bone, primarily involved in providing structural support and is not directly responsible for longitudinal growth. Fractures in the diaphysis do not affect the bone's length.

 

Option B. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone, which forms the joint surface. It plays a role in articulating with adjacent bones and, while important for bone structure, it does not contribute directly to longitudinal growth.

 

Option D. Metaphysis: This is the wide portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and the diaphysis. It is highly vascular and is a common site for bone tumors and infections but is not responsible for the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiphyseal plate is the region of the bone responsible for longitudinal growth, and fractures affecting this area can have significant implications on the bone's growth and development.

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Divalent metal transporter – 1

 

Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by divalent metal transporter-1 protein.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases and then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: This protein binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues, but it is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Ferroportin: This protein exports iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream but does not transport iron into the cells.

 

Option C. Hepcidin: This hormone regulates iron egress from enterocytes by inhibiting ferroportin but is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary transporter responsible for iron uptake into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen is the divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1).

questions.text:
Which of the provided statements about the muscle depicted in the image are true? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius
  2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius
  3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
  4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

Marked muscle in the image given is Rhomboid Major and minor.

 

 

1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. Both the rhomboideus major and minor muscles play a role in scapular retraction. This means they help pull the scapula (shoulder blade) toward the midline of the body, which is an action involved in retracting the scapula. The middle fibers of the trapezius muscle also contribute to scapular retraction.
     

2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. The Rhomboids retract the scapula superiorly and medially from the medial border of the scapula, this in turn assists in elevation of the scapula along with upper fibers of trapezius..
     

3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly:

 

  • True. When scapula is retracted and elevated along the medial border by rhomboids the glenoid cavity turns inferiorly (the socket of the shoulder joint).

     

Other Option:
 

4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly:

 

  • False. The primary action of the rhomboideus major and minor muscles is not to tilt the glenoid cavity superiorly. Their main functions involve scapular retraction and elevation, as discussed in statements 1 and 2. Tilted movement of the glenoid cavity superiorly is not a primary function associated with these muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rhomboid Major and Minor muscles are key players in scapular stabilization, involved in retraction, elevation, and downward rotation of the scapula, aligning the glenoid cavity in a position that supports optimal shoulder function.

questions.text: The following tzanck smear finding is seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV

 

Given tzanck smear finding is seen in HSV

 

The Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, which are characteristic of HSV infection. This test is commonly used to diagnose herpes infections, including HSV-1 and HSV-2, and can also detect varicella-zoster virus (the cause of chickenpox and shingles).

 

It used to diagnose some skin blistering disorders for ex: Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chicken pox: Incorrect. While Tzanck smears can be used to diagnose varicella-zoster virus infections, the specific question and provided image are more indicative of HSV.

 

Option C. HIV: Incorrect. HIV is not typically diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HIV diagnosis is usually confirmed with blood tests, including ELISA and Western blot.

 

Option D. HPV: Incorrect. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is not diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HPV diagnosis usually involves DNA tests and Pap smears for cervical lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tzanck smears are useful for diagnosing skin infections caused by herpes viruses, including HSV-1 and HSV-2. The presence of multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass chromatin is a hallmark of HSV infection.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for urinary incontinence following a hysterectomy. In the 3-swab test, the middle swab is stained with dye. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vesico-vaginal fistula

 

Explanation:

 

The 3-swab test is used to diagnose the presence and location of a fistula between the urinary tract and the genital tract following a hysterectomy.

 

 

3-swab Test:

 

  1. Three dry swabs are placed in the vagina:
    • Swab 1: Upper vagina
    • Swab 2: Middle vagina
    • Swab 3: Lower vagina
  2. Methylene blue dye is then injected into the bladder through a urinary catheter.
  3. After waiting for 5-10 minutes, the swabs are removed and examined for staining and wetness:
    • If the upper swab is wet but not stained with dye, it suggests a uretero-vaginal fistula since urine from the ureter is leaking into the vagina without dye.
    • If the middle swab is wet and stained with blue dye, it indicates a vesico-vaginal fistula because the dye from the bladder is leaking directly into the vagina through the fistula.
    • If the lower swab is stained and wet, it indicates a urethro-vaginal fistula.

 

In this case, the middle swab being stained with dye indicates that the fistula is between the bladder (vesica) and the vagina, confirming a vesico-vaginal fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uretero-vaginal fistula: The upper swab would be wet but not stained with dye.

 

Option C. Utero-vaginal fistula: This is not relevant post-hysterectomy as the uterus has been removed.

 

Option D. Urethro-vaginal fistula: The lower swab would be stained and wet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive 3-swab test with the middle swab stained with dye indicates a vesico-vaginal fistula, which is a common complication following a hysterectomy where the bladder and vagina are abnormally connected.

 

Note – the best IOC in this case is – CT Urography

questions.text: A combination of traumatic asphyxia and smothering is called: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burking

 

Burking:

 

  1. It includes homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxiation
  2. Named after Burke and Hare
  3. Burke used to sit on the chest of victim and close his mouth and nostrils by hand and Hare used to pull him round the room by feet.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gagging: Involves placing a gag in the victim’s mouth to prevent them from making noise, not necessarily causing death through asphyxia.

 

Option C. Choking: Refers to the obstruction of the airway by an internal object, preventing breathing.

 

Option D. Traumatic Asphyxia: A condition caused by severe compression of the chest, leading to impaired breathing and oxygen deprivation, but not necessarily combined with smothering.

 

Educational Objective:


Burking involves a deadly combination of traumatic asphyxia and smothering, making it a unique and specific method of homicide.

 

Ref: Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 119.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with alcoholic liver disease was given some anti-amoebic drug. Later the patient presented with nausea, vomiting, flushing and hypotension. What is the likely diagnosis? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disulfiram like reaction

 

The most likely diagnosis in this scenario is a disulfiram-like reaction. The timing of the symptoms in relation to the administration of an anti-amoebic drug, along with the specific symptoms mentioned, aligns well with this condition. Delirium tremens and alcohol withdrawal typically have different presentations and timing, and psychosis doesn't fit the symptom pattern described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by confusion, tremors, hallucinations, and agitation. It typically occurs several days after the last drink, not usually in direct response to medication.

 

Option B. Psychosis: While chronic alcoholism can be associated with psychosis, the symptoms described (nausea, vomiting, flushing, hypotension) are not typical for a primary psychiatric condition.

 

Option D. Alcohol Withdrawal: Symptoms of alcohol withdrawal typically include tremors, anxiety, nausea, vomiting, and seizures, but the specific combination of symptoms mentioned (particularly flushing and a direct connection to medication) is less typical for alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A disulfiram-like reaction can occur when certain medications, such as some anti-amoebic drugs like metronidazole, inhibit acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. This causes symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, flushing, and hypotension.

questions.text: Melanin is synthesized from which of the following amino acid? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tyrosine

 

Explanation

 

Correct Answer. Tyrosine, an amino acid, is the primary precursor for melanin synthesis. The process starts with the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA (dihydroxyphenylalanine) by the enzyme tyrosinase, followed by several steps leading to the formation of melanin. This pathway takes place in melanocytes, specialized cells found in the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor to serotonin and melatonin, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of melanin. Tryptophan's metabolic pathway is distinct from the pathway leading to melanin production.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Incorrect, but with a caveat. While phenylalanine itself is not directly used in melanin synthesis, it is important to note that phenylalanine can be converted into tyrosine in the body. Therefore, phenylalanine can be considered an indirect precursor to melanin. However, in the context of direct involvement in melanin synthesis, tyrosine is the correct answer.

 

Option D. Histidine: Histidine is another amino acid, but it is not involved in melanin synthesis. Instead, histidine plays roles in protein synthesis and the formation of histamine, a compound involved in immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanin is synthesized from tyrosine by following pathway.

 

 

Uses of tyrosine:

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 103

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albinism

 

Albinism is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. To have albinism, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene for albinism, one from each parent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G-6-PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner, not autosomal recessive. It affects males more often than females.

 

Option C. Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not autosomal recessive. A single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the condition.

 

Option D. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. It primarily affects males who inherit the mutated gene from their carrier mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to which of the following alcohols?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methyl alcohol

 

Option A. Methyl alcohol (Correct Answer): Hooch tragedies are typically associated with the consumption of illicit liquor that contains methanol. Methanol is toxic to the human body and can lead to serious health issues, including organ damage and even death, when consumed in significant amounts.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ethyl alcohol: Ethyl alcohol, also known as ethanol, is the type of alcohol commonly found in alcoholic beverages that are legally produced and regulated. It is not typically associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethylene glycol: Ethylene glycol is not related to hooch tragedies. It is a chemical compound used in products such as antifreeze and is highly toxic when ingested.

 

Option D. Hypoglycin: Hypoglycin is a naturally occurring toxin found in certain plants, such as the ackee fruit, and is not directly related to hooch tragedies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Country liquor can be categorised as spurious liquor or hooch when the amount of methane added could turn fatal. There are number of death cases reported every year due to consumption of such alcohol.

 

The metabolism of methyl alcohol is shown in figure below:

 

 

The formaldehyde and formic acid formed as products during the metabolism can cause severe metabolic acidosis, blindness and neurologic damage.

 

The treatment involves administration of ethanol or Fomepizole which act as competitive inhibitors of enzyme ADH and prevent the formation of these two products.

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary indirect

 

The European Hernia Society (EHS) classification for groin hernias includes a designation based on the location and whether the hernia is primary or recurrent. 

 

Refers to a primary hernia occurring laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, which protrudes through the deep inguinal ring. According to the EHS classification, a primary indirect hernia located in the lateral region with defect size 2 finger breadths (3 cm) is labelled as PL2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary direct: Refers to a primary hernia occurring medially to the inferior epigastric vessels, typically in Hesselbach's triangle. It is labelled as “PM”. 2 refers to size of defect as 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

 

Option C. Recurrent direct: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous direct hernia repair.

 

Option D. Recurrent indirect: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous indirect hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

According to the EHS classification, a hernia labeled as PL2 refers to a primary indirect inguinal hernia that is having a defect of size 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substrate

 

The active site of an enzyme is complementary to the substrate. The active site is a specific region of the enzyme where the substrate binds, forming an enzyme-substrate complex. This binding is highly specific and is often likened to a lock-and-key or induced-fit model. It provides a specific environment that facilitates the conversion of substrate into product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition state: The transition state refers to the intermediate state of a substrate as it undergoes a reaction and transforms into a product. While enzymes stabilize the transition state during catalysis, the active site itself is typically complementary to the substrate, not the transition state.

 

Option B. Allosteric activator: Allosteric activators bind to allosteric sites on enzymes, which are distinct from the active site. Allosteric regulation involves a change in the enzyme's conformation, affecting its activity.

 

Option D. Product: The active site is not complementary to the product. Once the reaction occurs, the product is released from the active site, allowing the enzyme to participate in another catalytic cycle with a new substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

questions.text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age > 10 years

 

Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.

 

Leukocyte count <50,000/mm, hyperdiploidy, trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, 17 indicate a better prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), prognostic factors such as age greater than 10 years, WBC count greater than 200,000/mm^3, male gender, presence of CNS involvement, and certain cytogenetic abnormalities such as t(9;22) or t(4;11) are associated with a poorer prognosis compared to their counterparts.

questions.text: When is the quadruple marker test done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 16 – 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The quadruple marker test is a prenatal screening test performed during the second trimester of pregnancy, typically between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

This test is used to assess the risk of certain genetic disorders, including Down syndrome (trisomy 21), trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

 

The quadruple marker test measures four specific substances in the mother's blood:

 

  1. Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  2. Free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (free beta-HCG)
  3. Inhibin A
  4. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

 

These markers provide information about the likelihood of certain fetal abnormalities.

 

Note - In the case of Down syndrome, free beta-HCG and inhibin A levels tend to be elevated, while unconjugated estriol and alpha-fetoprotein levels are typically decreased.

 

Educational objective:

 

The quadruple marker test is conducted between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation to screen for genetic disorders such as Down syndrome, trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

choices.text: Deletion of gene

questions.text: A case of complete gonadal dysgenesis was observed in a 46XY individual with female characteristics. The origin of complete gonadal dysgenesis lies in alterations of the SRY gene. What leads to complete gonadal dysgenesis in the SRY gene? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deletion of gene

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is typically associated with alterations in the SRY gene, which is crucial for initiating male sex determination. The SRY gene, located on the Y chromosome, directs the development of the gonads into testes. When this gene is deleted, it results in a failure to initiate testis formation, leading to a phenotypically female individual with a 46XY karyotype. In 10-15% of cases of 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, the SRY gene deletion is the underlying cause. This leads to a failure in developing male characteristics and results in complete gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point mutation: Point mutations in the SRY gene can also lead to gonadal dysgenesis, but this accounts for only a small percentage of cases. The mutations typically involve changes in the DNA sequence that alter the function of the SRY protein but do not necessarily delete the gene.

 

Option C. Translocation: Translocation refers to the movement of the SRY gene to another chromosome, which can sometimes lead to sex reversal if the SRY gene is present on an X chromosome in a 46XX individual. However, this is not the primary mechanism for complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual.

 

Option D. Inversion: Inversions involve a segment of the chromosome being reversed end to end. This type of chromosomal rearrangement is less commonly associated with gonadal dysgenesis and is not a typical cause of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is primarily caused by the deletion of the SRY gene, which leads to a failure in the development of male gonads, resulting in female characteristics.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with a history of nasal obstruction for the last 2 months. A CT scan was done, and the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antrochoanal polyp

 

The CT scan shows a mass originating from the maxillary sinus extending into the choana and nasopharynx, indicative of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps are benign lesions that arise from the maxillary sinus, extend through the sinus ostium, and grow into the nasopharynx. This causes nasal obstruction, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid hypertrophy: Adenoid hypertrophy occurs in the nasopharynx and is characterized by enlarged adenoids, leading to nasal obstruction and mouth breathing. It does not typically present with a mass extending from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option B. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs predominantly in adolescent males. It arises from the nasopharynx and extends into adjacent areas, not from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This malignant tumor arises from the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx. It usually presents with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The mass in the CT scan originating from the maxillary sinus is not consistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

An antrochoanal polyp originates from the maxillary sinus and extends through the choana into the nasopharynx, causing nasal obstruction. The presence of a gap between the tumor and the posterior pharyngeal wall on imaging, known as the "dot sign," supports this diagnosis.

choices.text: Prostate carcinoma
Breast carcinoma
Stomach carcinoma

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostate carcinoma

 

Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in prostate carcinoma.

 

Metastatic bone tumors: Metastatic bone tumors outnumber primary bone cancers as the most common type of skeletal malignancy.

 

Osteoblastic (or sclerotic) bone deposition is seen in prostate cancer, carcinoid, small cell lung cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma, and medulloblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast carcinoma: While breast cancer can metastasize to bone, it typically results in osteolytic (bone-destroying) rather than osteoblastic lesions.

 

Option C. Stomach carcinoma: Metastases from stomach cancer to bone are relatively rare and typically do not exhibit osteoblastic activity.

 

Option D. Bone carcinoma: This option is less specific and generally refers to primary bone cancers, which are different from the metastatic osteoblastic lesions seen in prostate cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoblastic metastases are a hallmark of prostate carcinoma, unlike breast and stomach carcinomas which are more likely to cause osteolytic or no bone lesions respectively.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhea. Laparoscopic finding is as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

The laparoscopic image shows an ovarian cyst filled with dark brown material, characteristic of a "chocolate cyst" or endometriotic cyst (endometrioma). Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside it, commonly on the ovaries, forming cysts filled with old blood. This is why they appear dark brown, resembling melted chocolate. The key symptom of endometriosis, as seen in this patient, is dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), which strongly supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, also known as mature cystic teratomas, contain various tissue types like hair, skin, and fat. They appear heterogeneous on imaging, often with calcifications, unlike the homogeneous blood-filled appearance of an endometriotic cyst.

 

Option C. PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): PID is an infection of the female reproductive organs, often presenting with pelvic pain, fever, and abnormal discharge. It does not typically result in cyst formation like what is seen in the image. PID usually shows inflamed and thickened structures rather than a distinct cystic mass.

 

Option D. Fibroid: Fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus, usually solid and non-cystic in appearance. They do not present with blood-filled cysts on the ovaries as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, commonly forming chocolate cysts in the ovaries, which present as dark, blood-filled cysts on laparoscopic examination.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.
